speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. A street.

speaker: BASTARD
text_entry: Enter FLAVIUS, MARULLUS, and certain Commoners

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Hence! home, you idle creatures get you home:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Is this a holiday? what! know you not,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Being mechanical, you ought not walk

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Upon a labouring day without the sign

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Of your profession? Speak, what trade art thou?

speaker: First Commoner
text_entry: Why, sir, a carpenter.

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Where is thy leather apron and thy rule?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: What dost thou with thy best apparel on?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: You, sir, what trade are you?

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: Truly, sir, in respect of a fine workman, I am but,

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: as you would say, a cobbler.

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: But what trade art thou? answer me directly.

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: A trade, sir, that, I hope, I may use with a safe

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: conscience; which is, indeed, sir, a mender of bad soles.

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: What trade, thou knave? thou naughty knave, what trade?

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: Nay, I beseech you, sir, be not out with me: yet,

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: if you be out, sir, I can mend you.

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: What meanest thou by that? mend me, thou saucy fellow!

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: Why, sir, cobble you.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Thou art a cobbler, art thou?

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: Truly, sir, all that I live by is with the awl: I

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: meddle with no tradesman's matters, nor women's

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: matters, but with awl. I am, indeed, sir, a surgeon

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: to old shoes; when they are in great danger, I

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: recover them. As proper men as ever trod upon

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: neat's leather have gone upon my handiwork.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: But wherefore art not in thy shop today?

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Why dost thou lead these men about the streets?

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: Truly, sir, to wear out their shoes, to get myself

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: into more work. But, indeed, sir, we make holiday,

speaker: Second Commoner
text_entry: to see Caesar and to rejoice in his triumph.

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Wherefore rejoice? What conquest brings he home?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: What tributaries follow him to Rome,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: To grace in captive bonds his chariot-wheels?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: You blocks, you stones, you worse than senseless things!

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: O you hard hearts, you cruel men of Rome,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Knew you not Pompey? Many a time and oft

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Have you climb'd up to walls and battlements,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: To towers and windows, yea, to chimney-tops,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Your infants in your arms, and there have sat

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: The livelong day, with patient expectation,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: To see great Pompey pass the streets of Rome:

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: And when you saw his chariot but appear,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Have you not made an universal shout,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: That Tiber trembled underneath her banks,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: To hear the replication of your sounds

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Made in her concave shores?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: And do you now put on your best attire?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: And do you now cull out a holiday?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: And do you now strew flowers in his way

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: That comes in triumph over Pompey's blood? Be gone!

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Run to your houses, fall upon your knees,

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: Pray to the gods to intermit the plague

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: That needs must light on this ingratitude.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Go, go, good countrymen, and, for this fault,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Assemble all the poor men of your sort;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Draw them to Tiber banks, and weep your tears

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Into the channel, till the lowest stream

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Do kiss the most exalted shores of all.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt all the Commoners

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: See whether their basest metal be not moved;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: They vanish tongue-tied in their guiltiness.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Go you down that way towards the Capitol;

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: This way will I disrobe the images,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: If you do find them deck'd with ceremonies.

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: May we do so?

speaker: MARULLUS
text_entry: You know it is the feast of Lupercal.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: It is no matter; let no images

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Be hung with Caesar's trophies. I'll about,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And drive away the vulgar from the streets:

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: So do you too, where you perceive them thick.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: These growing feathers pluck'd from Caesar's wing

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Will make him fly an ordinary pitch,

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Who else would soar above the view of men

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: And keep us all in servile fearfulness.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. A public place.

speaker: FLAVIUS
text_entry: Flourish. Enter CAESAR; ANTONY, for the course;  CALPURNIA, PORTIA, DECIUS BRUTUS, CICERO, BRUTUS,  CASSIUS, and CASCA; a great crowd following, among them a Soothsayer

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Calpurnia!

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Peace, ho! Caesar speaks.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Calpurnia!

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Here, my lord.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Stand you directly in Antonius' way,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: When he doth run his course. Antonius!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Caesar, my lord?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Forget not, in your speed, Antonius,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: To touch Calpurnia; for our elders say,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: The barren, touched in this holy chase,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Shake off their sterile curse.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I shall remember:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: When Caesar says 'do this,' it is perform'd.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Set on; and leave no ceremony out.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Flourish

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Caesar!

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Ha! who calls?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Bid every noise be still: peace yet again!

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Who is it in the press that calls on me?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I hear a tongue, shriller than all the music,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Cry 'Caesar!' Speak; Caesar is turn'd to hear.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What man is that?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A soothsayer bids you beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Set him before me; let me see his face.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Fellow, come from the throng; look upon Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What say'st thou to me now? speak once again.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Beware the ides of March.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: He is a dreamer; let us leave him: pass.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Sennet. Exeunt all except BRUTUS and CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Will you go see the order of the course?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not I.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I pray you, do.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I am not gamesome: I do lack some part

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of that quick spirit that is in Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me not hinder, Cassius, your desires;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll leave you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, I do observe you now of late:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I have not from your eyes that gentleness

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And show of love as I was wont to have:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You bear too stubborn and too strange a hand

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Over your friend that loves you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be not deceived: if I have veil'd my look,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I turn the trouble of my countenance

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Merely upon myself. Vexed I am

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of late with passions of some difference,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Conceptions only proper to myself,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which give some soil perhaps to my behaviors;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But let not therefore my good friends be grieved--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Among which number, Cassius, be you one--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nor construe any further my neglect,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than that poor Brutus, with himself at war,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Forgets the shows of love to other men.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then, Brutus, I have much mistook your passion;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: By means whereof this breast of mine hath buried

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thoughts of great value, worthy cogitations.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Tell me, good Brutus, can you see your face?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, Cassius; for the eye sees not itself,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But by reflection, by some other things.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Tis just:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And it is very much lamented, Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That you have no such mirrors as will turn

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Your hidden worthiness into your eye,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That you might see your shadow. I have heard,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where many of the best respect in Rome,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Except immortal Caesar, speaking of Brutus

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And groaning underneath this age's yoke,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have wish'd that noble Brutus had his eyes.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Into what dangers would you lead me, Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That you would have me seek into myself

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For that which is not in me?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Therefore, good Brutus, be prepared to hear:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And since you know you cannot see yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So well as by reflection, I, your glass,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Will modestly discover to yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That of yourself which you yet know not of.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And be not jealous on me, gentle Brutus:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Were I a common laugher, or did use

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To stale with ordinary oaths my love

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To every new protester; if you know

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That I do fawn on men and hug them hard

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And after scandal them, or if you know

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That I profess myself in banqueting

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To all the rout, then hold me dangerous.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Flourish, and shout

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What means this shouting? I do fear, the people

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Choose Caesar for their king.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ay, do you fear it?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then must I think you would not have it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I would not, Cassius; yet I love him well.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But wherefore do you hold me here so long?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What is it that you would impart to me?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If it be aught toward the general good,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Set honour in one eye and death i' the other,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And I will look on both indifferently,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For let the gods so speed me as I love

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The name of honour more than I fear death.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I know that virtue to be in you, Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As well as I do know your outward favour.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Well, honour is the subject of my story.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I cannot tell what you and other men

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Think of this life; but, for my single self,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I had as lief not be as live to be

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In awe of such a thing as I myself.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I was born free as Caesar; so were you:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: We both have fed as well, and we can both

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Endure the winter's cold as well as he:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For once, upon a raw and gusty day,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The troubled Tiber chafing with her shores,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Caesar said to me 'Darest thou, Cassius, now

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Leap in with me into this angry flood,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And swim to yonder point?' Upon the word,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Accoutred as I was, I plunged in

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And bade him follow; so indeed he did.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The torrent roar'd, and we did buffet it

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: With lusty sinews, throwing it aside

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And stemming it with hearts of controversy;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But ere we could arrive the point proposed,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Caesar cried 'Help me, Cassius, or I sink!'

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I, as Aeneas, our great ancestor,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Did from the flames of Troy upon his shoulder

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The old Anchises bear, so from the waves of Tiber

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Did I the tired Caesar. And this man

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is now become a god, and Cassius is

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A wretched creature and must bend his body,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If Caesar carelessly but nod on him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He had a fever when he was in Spain,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And when the fit was on him, I did mark

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: How he did shake: 'tis true, this god did shake;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: His coward lips did from their colour fly,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And that same eye whose bend doth awe the world

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Did lose his lustre: I did hear him groan:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ay, and that tongue of his that bade the Romans

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mark him and write his speeches in their books,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Alas, it cried 'Give me some drink, Titinius,'

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As a sick girl. Ye gods, it doth amaze me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A man of such a feeble temper should

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So get the start of the majestic world

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And bear the palm alone.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Shout. Flourish

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Another general shout!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do believe that these applauses are

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For some new honours that are heap'd on Caesar.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why, man, he doth bestride the narrow world

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Like a Colossus, and we petty men

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Walk under his huge legs and peep about

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To find ourselves dishonourable graves.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Men at some time are masters of their fates:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But in ourselves, that we are underlings.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus and Caesar: what should be in that 'Caesar'?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why should that name be sounded more than yours?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Write them together, yours is as fair a name;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Sound them, it doth become the mouth as well;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Weigh them, it is as heavy; conjure with 'em,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus will start a spirit as soon as Caesar.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now, in the names of all the gods at once,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon what meat doth this our Caesar feed,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That he is grown so great? Age, thou art shamed!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Rome, thou hast lost the breed of noble bloods!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When went there by an age, since the great flood,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But it was famed with more than with one man?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When could they say till now, that talk'd of Rome,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That her wide walls encompass'd but one man?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now is it Rome indeed and room enough,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When there is in it but one only man.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O, you and I have heard our fathers say,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There was a Brutus once that would have brook'd

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The eternal devil to keep his state in Rome

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As easily as a king.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That you do love me, I am nothing jealous;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What you would work me to, I have some aim:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How I have thought of this and of these times,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall recount hereafter; for this present,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I would not, so with love I might entreat you,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be any further moved. What you have said

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will consider; what you have to say

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will with patience hear, and find a time

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Both meet to hear and answer such high things.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Till then, my noble friend, chew upon this:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Brutus had rather be a villager

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than to repute himself a son of Rome

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Under these hard conditions as this time

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is like to lay upon us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I am glad that my weak words

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have struck but thus much show of fire from Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The games are done and Caesar is returning.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As they pass by, pluck Casca by the sleeve;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And he will, after his sour fashion, tell you

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What hath proceeded worthy note to-day.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Re-enter CAESAR and his Train

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will do so. But, look you, Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The angry spot doth glow on Caesar's brow,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And all the rest look like a chidden train:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Calpurnia's cheek is pale; and Cicero

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Looks with such ferret and such fiery eyes

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As we have seen him in the Capitol,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Being cross'd in conference by some senators.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Casca will tell us what the matter is.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Antonius!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Caesar?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Let me have men about me that are fat;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Sleek-headed men and such as sleep o' nights:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Yond Cassius has a lean and hungry look;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: He thinks too much: such men are dangerous.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Fear him not, Caesar; he's not dangerous;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He is a noble Roman and well given.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Would he were fatter! But I fear him not:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Yet if my name were liable to fear,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I do not know the man I should avoid

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: So soon as that spare Cassius. He reads much;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: He is a great observer and he looks

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Quite through the deeds of men: he loves no plays,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: As thou dost, Antony; he hears no music;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Seldom he smiles, and smiles in such a sort

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: As if he mock'd himself and scorn'd his spirit

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That could be moved to smile at any thing.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Such men as he be never at heart's ease

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Whiles they behold a greater than themselves,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And therefore are they very dangerous.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I rather tell thee what is to be fear'd

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Than what I fear; for always I am Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Come on my right hand, for this ear is deaf,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And tell me truly what thou think'st of him.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Sennet. Exeunt CAESAR and all his Train, but CASCA

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: You pull'd me by the cloak; would you speak with me?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ay, Casca; tell us what hath chanced to-day,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That Caesar looks so sad.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Why, you were with him, were you not?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I should not then ask Casca what had chanced.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Why, there was a crown offered him: and being

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: offered him, he put it by with the back of his hand,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: thus; and then the people fell a-shouting.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What was the second noise for?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Why, for that too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: They shouted thrice: what was the last cry for?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Why, for that too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Was the crown offered him thrice?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Ay, marry, was't, and he put it by thrice, every

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: time gentler than other, and at every putting-by

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: mine honest neighbours shouted.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Who offered him the crown?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Why, Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Tell us the manner of it, gentle Casca.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: I can as well be hanged as tell the manner of it:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: it was mere foolery; I did not mark it. I saw Mark

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Antony offer him a crown;--yet 'twas not a crown

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: neither, 'twas one of these coronets;--and, as I told

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: you, he put it by once: but, for all that, to my

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: thinking, he would fain have had it. Then he

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: offered it to him again; then he put it by again:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: but, to my thinking, he was very loath to lay his

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: fingers off it. And then he offered it the third

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: time; he put it the third time by: and still as he

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: refused it, the rabblement hooted and clapped their

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: chapped hands and threw up their sweaty night-caps

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: and uttered such a deal of stinking breath because

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Caesar refused the crown that it had almost choked

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Caesar; for he swounded and fell down at it: and

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: for mine own part, I durst not laugh, for fear of

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: opening my lips and receiving the bad air.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But, soft, I pray you: what, did Caesar swound?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: He fell down in the market-place, and foamed at

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: mouth, and was speechless.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Tis very like: he hath the failing sickness.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: No, Caesar hath it not; but you and I,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And honest Casca, we have the falling sickness.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: I know not what you mean by that; but, I am sure,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Caesar fell down. If the tag-rag people did not

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: clap him and hiss him, according as he pleased and

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: displeased them, as they use to do the players in

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: the theatre, I am no true man.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What said he when he came unto himself?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Marry, before he fell down, when he perceived the

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: common herd was glad he refused the crown, he

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: plucked me ope his doublet and offered them his

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: throat to cut. An I had been a man of any

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: occupation, if I would not have taken him at a word,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: I would I might go to hell among the rogues. And so

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: he fell. When he came to himself again, he said,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: If he had done or said any thing amiss, he desired

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: their worships to think it was his infirmity. Three

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: or four wenches, where I stood, cried 'Alas, good

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: soul!' and forgave him with all their hearts: but

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: there's no heed to be taken of them; if Caesar had

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: stabbed their mothers, they would have done no less.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And after that, he came, thus sad, away?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Did Cicero say any thing?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Ay, he spoke Greek.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To what effect?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Nay, an I tell you that, Ill ne'er look you i' the

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: face again: but those that understood him smiled at

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: one another and shook their heads; but, for mine own

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: part, it was Greek to me. I could tell you more

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: news too: Marullus and Flavius, for pulling scarfs

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: off Caesar's images, are put to silence. Fare you

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: well. There was more foolery yet, if I could

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: remember it.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Will you sup with me to-night, Casca?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: No, I am promised forth.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Will you dine with me to-morrow?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Ay, if I be alive and your mind hold and your dinner

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: worth the eating.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Good: I will expect you.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Do so. Farewell, both.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What a blunt fellow is this grown to be!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He was quick mettle when he went to school.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So is he now in execution

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of any bold or noble enterprise,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: However he puts on this tardy form.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This rudeness is a sauce to his good wit,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Which gives men stomach to digest his words

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: With better appetite.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And so it is. For this time I will leave you:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To-morrow, if you please to speak with me,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will come home to you; or, if you will,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come home to me, and I will wait for you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I will do so: till then, think of the world.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exit BRUTUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Well, Brutus, thou art noble; yet, I see,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thy honourable metal may be wrought

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: From that it is disposed: therefore it is meet

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That noble minds keep ever with their likes;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For who so firm that cannot be seduced?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Caesar doth bear me hard; but he loves Brutus:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If I were Brutus now and he were Cassius,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He should not humour me. I will this night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In several hands, in at his windows throw,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As if they came from several citizens,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Writings all tending to the great opinion

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That Rome holds of his name; wherein obscurely

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Caesar's ambition shall be glanced at:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And after this let Caesar seat him sure;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For we will shake him, or worse days endure.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. A street.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thunder and lightning. Enter from opposite sides, CASCA, with his sword drawn, and CICERO

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Good even, Casca: brought you Caesar home?

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Why are you breathless? and why stare you so?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Are not you moved, when all the sway of earth

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Shakes like a thing unfirm? O Cicero,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: I have seen tempests, when the scolding winds

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Have rived the knotty oaks, and I have seen

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: The ambitious ocean swell and rage and foam,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: To be exalted with the threatening clouds:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: But never till to-night, never till now,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Did I go through a tempest dropping fire.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Either there is a civil strife in heaven,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Or else the world, too saucy with the gods,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Incenses them to send destruction.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Why, saw you any thing more wonderful?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: A common slave--you know him well by sight--

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Held up his left hand, which did flame and burn

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Like twenty torches join'd, and yet his hand,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Not sensible of fire, remain'd unscorch'd.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Besides--I ha' not since put up my sword--

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Against the Capitol I met a lion,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Who glared upon me, and went surly by,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Without annoying me: and there were drawn

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Upon a heap a hundred ghastly women,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Transformed with their fear; who swore they saw

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Men all in fire walk up and down the streets.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And yesterday the bird of night did sit

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Even at noon-day upon the market-place,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Hooting and shrieking. When these prodigies

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Do so conjointly meet, let not men say

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: 'These are their reasons; they are natural;'

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: For, I believe, they are portentous things

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Unto the climate that they point upon.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Indeed, it is a strange-disposed time:

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: But men may construe things after their fashion,

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Clean from the purpose of the things themselves.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Come Caesar to the Capitol to-morrow?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: He doth; for he did bid Antonius

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Send word to you he would be there to-morrow.

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Good night then, Casca: this disturbed sky

speaker: CICERO
text_entry: Is not to walk in.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Farewell, Cicero.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Exit CICERO

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Enter CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Who's there?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: A Roman.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Casca, by your voice.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Your ear is good. Cassius, what night is this!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A very pleasing night to honest men.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Who ever knew the heavens menace so?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Those that have known the earth so full of faults.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For my part, I have walk'd about the streets,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Submitting me unto the perilous night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And, thus unbraced, Casca, as you see,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have bared my bosom to the thunder-stone;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And when the cross blue lightning seem'd to open

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The breast of heaven, I did present myself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Even in the aim and very flash of it.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: But wherefore did you so much tempt the heavens?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: It is the part of men to fear and tremble,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: When the most mighty gods by tokens send

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Such dreadful heralds to astonish us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You are dull, Casca, and those sparks of life

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That should be in a Roman you do want,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Or else you use not. You look pale and gaze

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And put on fear and cast yourself in wonder,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To see the strange impatience of the heavens:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But if you would consider the true cause

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why all these fires, why all these gliding ghosts,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why birds and beasts from quality and kind,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why old men fool and children calculate,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why all these things change from their ordinance

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Their natures and preformed faculties

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To monstrous quality,--why, you shall find

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That heaven hath infused them with these spirits,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To make them instruments of fear and warning

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Unto some monstrous state.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now could I, Casca, name to thee a man

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Most like this dreadful night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That thunders, lightens, opens graves, and roars

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As doth the lion in the Capitol,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A man no mightier than thyself or me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In personal action, yet prodigious grown

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And fearful, as these strange eruptions are.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: 'Tis Caesar that you mean; is it not, Cassius?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let it be who it is: for Romans now

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have thews and limbs like to their ancestors;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But, woe the while! our fathers' minds are dead,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And we are govern'd with our mothers' spirits;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Our yoke and sufferance show us womanish.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Indeed, they say the senators tomorrow

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Mean to establish Caesar as a king;

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And he shall wear his crown by sea and land,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: In every place, save here in Italy.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I know where I will wear this dagger then;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cassius from bondage will deliver Cassius:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Therein, ye gods, you make the weak most strong;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Therein, ye gods, you tyrants do defeat:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Nor stony tower, nor walls of beaten brass,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Nor airless dungeon, nor strong links of iron,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Can be retentive to the strength of spirit;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But life, being weary of these worldly bars,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Never lacks power to dismiss itself.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If I know this, know all the world besides,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That part of tyranny that I do bear

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I can shake off at pleasure.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thunder still

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: So can I:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: So every bondman in his own hand bears

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: The power to cancel his captivity.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And why should Caesar be a tyrant then?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Poor man! I know he would not be a wolf,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But that he sees the Romans are but sheep:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He were no lion, were not Romans hinds.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Those that with haste will make a mighty fire

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Begin it with weak straws: what trash is Rome,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What rubbish and what offal, when it serves

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For the base matter to illuminate

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So vile a thing as Caesar! But, O grief,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where hast thou led me? I perhaps speak this

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Before a willing bondman; then I know

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My answer must be made. But I am arm'd,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And dangers are to me indifferent.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: You speak to Casca, and to such a man

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: That is no fleering tell-tale. Hold, my hand:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Be factious for redress of all these griefs,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And I will set this foot of mine as far

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: As who goes farthest.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There's a bargain made.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now know you, Casca, I have moved already

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Some certain of the noblest-minded Romans

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To undergo with me an enterprise

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of honourable-dangerous consequence;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And I do know, by this, they stay for me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In Pompey's porch: for now, this fearful night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There is no stir or walking in the streets;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And the complexion of the element

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In favour's like the work we have in hand,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Most bloody, fiery, and most terrible.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Stand close awhile, for here comes one in haste.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Tis Cinna; I do know him by his gait;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He is a friend.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Enter CINNA

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cinna, where haste you so?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: To find out you. Who's that? Metellus Cimber?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: No, it is Casca; one incorporate

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To our attempts. Am I not stay'd for, Cinna?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: I am glad on 't. What a fearful night is this!

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: There's two or three of us have seen strange sights.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Am I not stay'd for? tell me.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Yes, you are.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: O Cassius, if you could

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: But win the noble Brutus to our party--

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Be you content: good Cinna, take this paper,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And look you lay it in the praetor's chair,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where Brutus may but find it; and throw this

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In at his window; set this up with wax

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon old Brutus' statue: all this done,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Repair to Pompey's porch, where you shall find us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is Decius Brutus and Trebonius there?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: All but Metellus Cimber; and he's gone

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: To seek you at your house. Well, I will hie,

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: And so bestow these papers as you bade me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That done, repair to Pompey's theatre.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exit CINNA

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come, Casca, you and I will yet ere day

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: See Brutus at his house: three parts of him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is ours already, and the man entire

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon the next encounter yields him ours.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: O, he sits high in all the people's hearts:

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: And that which would appear offence in us,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: His countenance, like richest alchemy,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Will change to virtue and to worthiness.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Him and his worth and our great need of him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You have right well conceited. Let us go,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For it is after midnight; and ere day

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: We will awake him and be sure of him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. BRUTUS's orchard.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What, Lucius, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I cannot, by the progress of the stars,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give guess how near to day. Lucius, I say!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When, Lucius, when? awake, I say! what, Lucius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Call'd you, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When it is lighted, come and call me here.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I will, my lord.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It must be by his death: and for my part,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know no personal cause to spurn at him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But for the general. He would be crown'd:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How that might change his nature, there's the question.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is the bright day that brings forth the adder;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And that craves wary walking. Crown him?--that;--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And then, I grant, we put a sting in him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That at his will he may do danger with.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The abuse of greatness is, when it disjoins

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Remorse from power: and, to speak truth of Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have not known when his affections sway'd

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: More than his reason. But 'tis a common proof,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That lowliness is young ambition's ladder,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Whereto the climber-upward turns his face;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But when he once attains the upmost round.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He then unto the ladder turns his back,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By which he did ascend. So Caesar may.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then, lest he may, prevent. And, since the quarrel

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Will bear no colour for the thing he is,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fashion it thus; that what he is, augmented,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Would run to these and these extremities:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And therefore think him as a serpent's egg

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which, hatch'd, would, as his kind, grow mischievous,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And kill him in the shell.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The taper burneth in your closet, sir.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Searching the window for a flint, I found

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This paper, thus seal'd up; and, I am sure,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: It did not lie there when I went to bed.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Gives him the letter

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get you to bed again; it is not day.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is not to-morrow, boy, the ides of March?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I know not, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Look in the calendar, and bring me word.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I will, sir.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The exhalations whizzing in the air

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give so much light that I may read by them.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Opens the letter and reads

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake, and see thyself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall Rome,  and c. Speak, strike, redress!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake!'

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Such instigations have been often dropp'd

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where I have took them up.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Shall Rome,  and c.' Thus must I piece it out:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My ancestors did from the streets of Rome

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The Tarquin drive, when he was call'd a king.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Speak, strike, redress!' Am I entreated

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If the redress will follow, thou receivest

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sir, March is wasted fourteen days.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have not slept.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Between the acting of a dreadful thing

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And the first motion, all the interim is

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Like a phantasma, or a hideous dream:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The Genius and the mortal instruments

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Are then in council; and the state of man,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Like to a little kingdom, suffers then

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The nature of an insurrection.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Who doth desire to see you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is he alone?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No, sir, there are moe with him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do you know them?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No, sir; their hats are pluck'd about their ears,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And half their faces buried in their cloaks,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That by no means I may discover them

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: By any mark of favour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let 'em enter.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They are the faction. O conspiracy,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When evils are most free? O, then by day

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hide it in smiles and affability:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For if thou path, thy native semblance on,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not Erebus itself were dim enough

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To hide thee from prevention.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter the conspirators, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, CINNA, METELLUS CIMBER, and TREBONIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I think we are too bold upon your rest:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Good morrow, Brutus; do we trouble you?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have been up this hour, awake all night.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Know I these men that come along with you?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Yes, every man of them, and no man here

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But honours you; and every one doth wish

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You had but that opinion of yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Which every noble Roman bears of you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This is Trebonius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is welcome hither.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This, Decius Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is welcome too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They are all welcome.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What watchful cares do interpose themselves

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Betwixt your eyes and night?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Shall I entreat a word?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: BRUTUS and CASSIUS whisper

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Here lies the east: doth not the day break here?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: No.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: O, pardon, sir, it doth; and yon gray lines

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: That fret the clouds are messengers of day.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: You shall confess that you are both deceived.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Which is a great way growing on the south,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Weighing the youthful season of the year.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Some two months hence up higher toward the north

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: He first presents his fire; and the high east

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give me your hands all over, one by one.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And let us swear our resolution.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, not an oath: if not the face of men,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The sufferance of our souls, the time's abuse,--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If these be motives weak, break off betimes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And every man hence to his idle bed;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: So let high-sighted tyranny range on,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Till each man drop by lottery. But if these,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As I am sure they do, bear fire enough

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To kindle cowards and to steel with valour

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What need we any spur but our own cause,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To prick us to redress? what other bond

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than secret Romans, that have spoke the word,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And will not palter? and what other oath

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than honesty to honesty engaged,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That this shall be, or we will fall for it?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The even virtue of our enterprise,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To think that or our cause or our performance

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Did need an oath; when every drop of blood

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That every Roman bears, and nobly bears,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is guilty of a several bastardy,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If he do break the smallest particle

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But what of Cicero? shall we sound him?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I think he will stand very strong with us.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Let us not leave him out.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: No, by no means.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Will purchase us a good opinion

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: And buy men's voices to commend our deeds:

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: It shall be said, his judgment ruled our hands;

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear,

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: But all be buried in his gravity.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, name him not: let us not break with him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For he will never follow any thing

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That other men begin.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then leave him out.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Indeed he is not fit.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Decius, well urged: I think it is not meet,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Should outlive Caesar: we shall find of him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A shrewd contriver; and, you know, his means,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If he improve them, may well stretch so far

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As to annoy us all: which to prevent,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To cut the head off and then hack the limbs,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Like wrath in death and envy afterwards;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For Antony is but a limb of Caesar:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And in the spirit of men there is no blood:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And not dismember Caesar! But, alas,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar must bleed for it! And, gentle friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let's kill him boldly, but not wrathfully;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And let our hearts, as subtle masters do,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Stir up their servants to an act of rage,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And after seem to chide 'em. This shall make

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our purpose necessary and not envious:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which so appearing to the common eyes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And for Mark Antony, think not of him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For he can do no more than Caesar's arm

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When Caesar's head is off.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Yet I fear him;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If he love Caesar, all that he can do

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is to himself, take thought and die for Caesar:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And that were much he should; for he is given

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To sports, to wildness and much company.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: There is no fear in him; let him not die;

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: For he will live, and laugh at this hereafter.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Clock strikes

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Peace! count the clock.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The clock hath stricken three.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: 'Tis time to part.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But it is doubtful yet,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Whether Caesar will come forth to-day, or no;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For he is superstitious grown of late,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Quite from the main opinion he held once

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of fantasy, of dreams and ceremonies:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: It may be, these apparent prodigies,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The unaccustom'd terror of this night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And the persuasion of his augurers,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: May hold him from the Capitol to-day.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Never fear that: if he be so resolved,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: I can o'ersway him; for he loves to hear

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: That unicorns may be betray'd with trees,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Lions with toils and men with flatterers;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: But when I tell him he hates flatterers,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: He says he does, being then most flattered.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me work;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: For I can give his humour the true bent,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And I will bring him to the Capitol.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey:

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: I wonder none of you have thought of him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now, good Metellus, go along by him:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The morning comes upon 's: we'll leave you, Brutus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And, friends, disperse yourselves; but all remember

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let not our looks put on our purposes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But bear it as our Roman actors do,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With untired spirits and formal constancy:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And so good morrow to you every one.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which busy care draws in the brains of men;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter PORTIA

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Brutus, my lord!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Portia, what mean you? wherefore rise you now?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is not for your health thus to commit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nor for yours neither. You've ungently, Brutus,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Stole from my bed: and yesternight, at supper,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You suddenly arose, and walk'd about,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Musing and sighing, with your arms across,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And when I ask'd you what the matter was,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You stared upon me with ungentle looks;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But, with an angry wafture of your hand,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Gave sign for me to leave you: so I did;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Fearing to strengthen that impatience

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which seem'd too much enkindled, and withal

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Hoping it was but an effect of humour,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which sometime hath his hour with every man.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And could it work so much upon your shape

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As it hath much prevail'd on your condition,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I am not well in health, and that is all.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: He would embrace the means to come by it.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is Brutus sick? and is it physical

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To walk unbraced and suck up the humours

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To dare the vile contagion of the night

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You have some sick offence within your mind,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which, by the right and virtue of my place,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I ought to know of: and, upon my knees,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: By all your vows of love and that great vow

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which did incorporate and make us one,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That you unfold to me, yourself, your half,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Why you are heavy, and what men to-night

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Have had to resort to you: for here have been

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Some six or seven, who did hide their faces

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Even from darkness.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Kneel not, gentle Portia.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is it excepted I should know no secrets

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That appertain to you? Am I yourself

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But, as it were, in sort or limitation,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You are my true and honourable wife,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As dear to me as are the ruddy drops

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That visit my sad heart

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If this were true, then should I know this secret.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I grant I am a woman; but withal

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I grant I am a woman; but withal

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Think you I am no stronger than my sex,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Being so father'd and so husbanded?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose 'em:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I have made strong proof of my constancy,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Giving myself a voluntary wound

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Here, in the thigh: can I bear that with patience.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And not my husband's secrets?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O ye gods,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Render me worthy of this noble wife!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hark, hark! one knocks: Portia, go in awhile;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And by and by thy bosom shall partake

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The secrets of my heart.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: All my engagements I will construe to thee,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: All the charactery of my sad brows:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Leave me with haste.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit PORTIA

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius, who's that knocks?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS with LIGARIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: He is a sick man that would speak with you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! how?

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Any exploit worthy the name of honour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: By all the gods that Romans bow before,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Brave son, derived from honourable loins!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: My mortified spirit. Now bid me run,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: And I will strive with things impossible;

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: But are not some whole that we must make sick?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That must we also. What it is, my Caius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall unfold to thee, as we are going

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To whom it must be done.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Set on your foot,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: And with a heart new-fired I follow you,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: To do I know not what: but it sufficeth

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: That Brutus leads me on.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Follow me, then.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE II. CAESAR's house.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thunder and lightning. Enter CAESAR, in his night-gown

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Nor heaven nor earth have been at peace to-night:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Thrice hath Calpurnia in her sleep cried out,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: 'Help, ho! they murder Caesar!' Who's within?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: Servant
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Go bid the priests do present sacrifice

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And bring me their opinions of success.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I will, my lord.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Enter CALPURNIA

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: What mean you, Caesar? think you to walk forth?

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: You shall not stir out of your house to-day.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Caesar shall forth: the things that threaten'd me

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Ne'er look'd but on my back; when they shall see

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: The face of Caesar, they are vanished.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Caesar, I never stood on ceremonies,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Yet now they fright me. There is one within,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Besides the things that we have heard and seen,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Recounts most horrid sights seen by the watch.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: A lioness hath whelped in the streets;

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: And graves have yawn'd, and yielded up their dead;

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Fierce fiery warriors fought upon the clouds,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: In ranks and squadrons and right form of war,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Which drizzled blood upon the Capitol;

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: The noise of battle hurtled in the air,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Horses did neigh, and dying men did groan,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: And ghosts did shriek and squeal about the streets.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: O Caesar! these things are beyond all use,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: And I do fear them.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What can be avoided

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Whose end is purposed by the mighty gods?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Yet Caesar shall go forth; for these predictions

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Are to the world in general as to Caesar.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: When beggars die, there are no comets seen;

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: The heavens themselves blaze forth the death of princes.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Cowards die many times before their deaths;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: The valiant never taste of death but once.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Of all the wonders that I yet have heard.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: It seems to me most strange that men should fear;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Seeing that death, a necessary end,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Will come when it will come.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Re-enter Servant

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What say the augurers?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: They would not have you to stir forth to-day.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Plucking the entrails of an offering forth,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: They could not find a heart within the beast.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: The gods do this in shame of cowardice:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Caesar should be a beast without a heart,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: If he should stay at home to-day for fear.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: No, Caesar shall not: danger knows full well

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That Caesar is more dangerous than he:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: We are two lions litter'd in one day,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And I the elder and more terrible:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And Caesar shall go forth.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Alas, my lord,

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Your wisdom is consumed in confidence.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Do not go forth to-day: call it my fear

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: That keeps you in the house, and not your own.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: We'll send Mark Antony to the senate-house:

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: And he shall say you are not well to-day:

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Let me, upon my knee, prevail in this.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Mark Antony shall say I am not well,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And, for thy humour, I will stay at home.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Enter DECIUS BRUTUS

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Here's Decius Brutus, he shall tell them so.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar, all hail! good morrow, worthy Caesar:

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: I come to fetch you to the senate-house.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And you are come in very happy time,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: To bear my greeting to the senators

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And tell them that I will not come to-day:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Cannot, is false, and that I dare not, falser:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I will not come to-day: tell them so, Decius.

speaker: CALPURNIA
text_entry: Say he is sick.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Shall Caesar send a lie?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Have I in conquest stretch'd mine arm so far,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: To be afraid to tell graybeards the truth?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Decius, go tell them Caesar will not come.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Most mighty Caesar, let me know some cause,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Lest I be laugh'd at when I tell them so.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: The cause is in my will: I will not come;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That is enough to satisfy the senate.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: But for your private satisfaction,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Because I love you, I will let you know:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Calpurnia here, my wife, stays me at home:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: She dreamt to-night she saw my statua,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Which, like a fountain with an hundred spouts,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Did run pure blood: and many lusty Romans

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Came smiling, and did bathe their hands in it:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And these does she apply for warnings, and portents,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And evils imminent; and on her knee

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Hath begg'd that I will stay at home to-day.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: This dream is all amiss interpreted;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: It was a vision fair and fortunate:

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Your statue spouting blood in many pipes,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: In which so many smiling Romans bathed,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Signifies that from you great Rome shall suck

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Reviving blood, and that great men shall press

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: For tinctures, stains, relics and cognizance.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: This by Calpurnia's dream is signified.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And this way have you well expounded it.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: I have, when you have heard what I can say:

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And know it now: the senate have concluded

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: To give this day a crown to mighty Caesar.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: If you shall send them word you will not come,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Their minds may change. Besides, it were a mock

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Apt to be render'd, for some one to say

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Break up the senate till another time,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: When Caesar's wife shall meet with better dreams.'

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: If Caesar hide himself, shall they not whisper

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Lo, Caesar is afraid'?

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Pardon me, Caesar; for my dear dear love

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: To our proceeding bids me tell you this;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And reason to my love is liable.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: How foolish do your fears seem now, Calpurnia!

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I am ashamed I did yield to them.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Give me my robe, for I will go.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Enter PUBLIUS, BRUTUS, LIGARIUS, METELLUS, CASCA, TREBONIUS, and CINNA

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And look where Publius is come to fetch me.

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Good morrow, Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Welcome, Publius.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What, Brutus, are you stirr'd so early too?

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Good morrow, Casca. Caius Ligarius,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Caesar was ne'er so much your enemy

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: As that same ague which hath made you lean.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What is 't o'clock?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar, 'tis strucken eight.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I thank you for your pains and courtesy.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Enter ANTONY

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: See! Antony, that revels long o' nights,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Is notwithstanding up. Good morrow, Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So to most noble Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Bid them prepare within:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I am to blame to be thus waited for.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Now, Cinna: now, Metellus: what, Trebonius!

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I have an hour's talk in store for you;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Remember that you call on me to-day:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Be near me, that I may remember you.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Caesar, I will:

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Aside

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: and so near will I be,

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: That your best friends shall wish I had been further.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Good friends, go in, and taste some wine with me;

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And we, like friends, will straightway go together.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: [Aside]  That every like is not the same, O Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The heart of Brutus yearns to think upon!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE III. A street near the Capitol.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter ARTEMIDORUS, reading a paper

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: 'Caesar, beware of Brutus; take heed of Cassius;

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: come not near Casca; have an eye to Cinna, trust not

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Trebonius: mark well Metellus Cimber: Decius Brutus

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: loves thee not: thou hast wronged Caius Ligarius.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: There is but one mind in all these men, and it is

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: bent against Caesar. If thou beest not immortal,

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: look about you: security gives way to conspiracy.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: The mighty gods defend thee! Thy lover,

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: 'ARTEMIDORUS.'

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Here will I stand till Caesar pass along,

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: And as a suitor will I give him this.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: My heart laments that virtue cannot live

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Out of the teeth of emulation.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: If thou read this, O Caesar, thou mayst live;

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: If not, the Fates with traitors do contrive.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the same street, before the house of BRUTUS.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Enter PORTIA and LUCIUS

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I prithee, boy, run to the senate-house;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Stay not to answer me, but get thee gone:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Why dost thou stay?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: To know my errand, madam.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I would have had thee there, and here again,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Ere I can tell thee what thou shouldst do there.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: O constancy, be strong upon my side,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Set a huge mountain 'tween my heart and tongue!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I have a man's mind, but a woman's might.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: How hard it is for women to keep counsel!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Art thou here yet?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Madam, what should I do?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Run to the Capitol, and nothing else?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And so return to you, and nothing else?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Yes, bring me word, boy, if thy lord look well,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: For he went sickly forth: and take good note

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What Caesar doth, what suitors press to him.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Hark, boy! what noise is that?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I hear none, madam.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Prithee, listen well;

speaker: PORTIA
