text_entry: I heard a bustling rumour, like a fray,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And the wind brings it from the Capitol.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sooth, madam, I hear nothing.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter the Soothsayer

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Come hither, fellow: which way hast thou been?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: At mine own house, good lady.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: What is't o'clock?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: About the ninth hour, lady.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is Caesar yet gone to the Capitol?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Madam, not yet: I go to take my stand,

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: To see him pass on to the Capitol.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Thou hast some suit to Caesar, hast thou not?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: That I have, lady: if it will please Caesar

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: To be so good to Caesar as to hear me,

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: I shall beseech him to befriend himself.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Why, know'st thou any harm's intended towards him?

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: None that I know will be, much that I fear may chance.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Good morrow to you. Here the street is narrow:

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: The throng that follows Caesar at the heels,

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Of senators, of praetors, common suitors,

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Will crowd a feeble man almost to death:

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: I'll get me to a place more void, and there

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Speak to great Caesar as he comes along.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I must go in. Ay me, how weak a thing

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The heart of woman is! O Brutus,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: The heavens speed thee in thine enterprise!

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Sure, the boy heard me: Brutus hath a suit

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That Caesar will not grant. O, I grow faint.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Run, Lucius, and commend me to my lord;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Say I am merry: come to me again,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And bring me word what he doth say to thee.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Exeunt severally

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: ACT III

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. Before the Capitol; the Senate sitting above.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A crowd of people; among them ARTEMIDORUS and the  Soothsayer. Flourish. Enter CAESAR, BRUTUS,  CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, METELLUS CIMBER,  TREBONIUS, CINNA, ANTONY, LEPIDUS, POPILIUS, PUBLIUS, and others

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: [To the Soothsayer]  The ides of March are come.

speaker: Soothsayer
text_entry: Ay, Caesar; but not gone.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Hail, Caesar! read this schedule.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Trebonius doth desire you to o'erread,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: At your best leisure, this his humble suit.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: O Caesar, read mine first; for mine's a suit

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: That touches Caesar nearer: read it, great Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What touches us ourself shall be last served.

speaker: ARTEMIDORUS
text_entry: Delay not, Caesar; read it instantly.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What, is the fellow mad?

speaker: PUBLIUS
text_entry: Sirrah, give place.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What, urge you your petitions in the street?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come to the Capitol.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: CAESAR goes up to the Senate-House, the rest following

speaker: POPILIUS
text_entry: I wish your enterprise to-day may thrive.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What enterprise, Popilius?

speaker: POPILIUS
text_entry: Fare you well.

speaker: POPILIUS
text_entry: Advances to CAESAR

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What said Popilius Lena?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He wish'd to-day our enterprise might thrive.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I fear our purpose is discovered.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Look, how he makes to Caesar; mark him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Casca, be sudden, for we fear prevention.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, what shall be done? If this be known,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cassius or Caesar never shall turn back,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For I will slay myself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cassius, be constant:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Popilius Lena speaks not of our purposes;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For, look, he smiles, and Caesar doth not change.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Trebonius knows his time; for, look you, Brutus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: He draws Mark Antony out of the way.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt ANTONY and TREBONIUS

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Where is Metellus Cimber? Let him go,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And presently prefer his suit to Caesar.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is address'd: press near and second him.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Casca, you are the first that rears your hand.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Are we all ready? What is now amiss

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That Caesar and his senate must redress?

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Most high, most mighty, and most puissant Caesar,

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Metellus Cimber throws before thy seat

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: An humble heart,--

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Kneeling

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I must prevent thee, Cimber.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: These couchings and these lowly courtesies

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Might fire the blood of ordinary men,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: And turn pre-ordinance and first decree

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Into the law of children. Be not fond,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: To think that Caesar bears such rebel blood

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: That will be thaw'd from the true quality

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: With that which melteth fools; I mean, sweet words,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Low-crooked court'sies and base spaniel-fawning.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Thy brother by decree is banished:

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: If thou dost bend and pray and fawn for him,

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: I spurn thee like a cur out of my way.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Know, Caesar doth not wrong, nor without cause

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Will he be satisfied.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Is there no voice more worthy than my own

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: To sound more sweetly in great Caesar's ear

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: For the repealing of my banish'd brother?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I kiss thy hand, but not in flattery, Caesar;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Desiring thee that Publius Cimber may

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have an immediate freedom of repeal.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: What, Brutus!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Pardon, Caesar; Caesar, pardon:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As low as to thy foot doth Cassius fall,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To beg enfranchisement for Publius Cimber.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I could be well moved, if I were as you:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If I could pray to move, prayers would move me:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But I am constant as the northern star,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of whose true-fix'd and resting quality

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: There is no fellow in the firmament.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The skies are painted with unnumber'd sparks,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: They are all fire and every one doth shine,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But there's but one in all doth hold his place:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So in the world; 'tis furnish'd well with men,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And men are flesh and blood, and apprehensive;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Yet in the number I do know but one

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That unassailable holds on his rank,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Unshaked of motion: and that I am he,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let me a little show it, even in this;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That I was constant Cimber should be banish'd,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And constant do remain to keep him so.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: O Caesar,--

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Hence! wilt thou lift up Olympus?

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Great Caesar,--

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Doth not Brutus bootless kneel?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Speak, hands for me!

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: CASCA first, then the other Conspirators and BRUTUS stab CAESAR

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Et tu, Brute! Then fall, Caesar.

speaker: CAESAR
text_entry: Dies

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Liberty! Freedom! Tyranny is dead!

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Run hence, proclaim, cry it about the streets.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Some to the common pulpits, and cry out

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Liberty, freedom, and enfranchisement!'

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: People and senators, be not affrighted;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fly not; stand stiff: ambition's debt is paid.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Go to the pulpit, Brutus.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And Cassius too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where's Publius?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Here, quite confounded with this mutiny.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Stand fast together, lest some friend of Caesar's

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Should chance--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Talk not of standing. Publius, good cheer;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is no harm intended to your person,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nor to no Roman else: so tell them, Publius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And leave us, Publius; lest that the people,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Rushing on us, should do your age some mischief.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do so: and let no man abide this deed,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But we the doers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter TREBONIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Where is Antony?

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Fled to his house amazed:

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Men, wives and children stare, cry out and run

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: As it were doomsday.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fates, we will know your pleasures:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That we shall die, we know; 'tis but the time

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And drawing days out, that men stand upon.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why, he that cuts off twenty years of life

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cuts off so many years of fearing death.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Grant that, and then is death a benefit:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: So are we Caesar's friends, that have abridged

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: His time of fearing death. Stoop, Romans, stoop,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And let us bathe our hands in Caesar's blood

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Up to the elbows, and besmear our swords:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then walk we forth, even to the market-place,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, waving our red weapons o'er our heads,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let's all cry 'Peace, freedom and liberty!'

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stoop, then, and wash. How many ages hence

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Shall this our lofty scene be acted over

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In states unborn and accents yet unknown!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How many times shall Caesar bleed in sport,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That now on Pompey's basis lies along

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No worthier than the dust!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So oft as that shall be,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So often shall the knot of us be call'd

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The men that gave their country liberty.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: What, shall we forth?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ay, every man away:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus shall lead; and we will grace his heels

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: With the most boldest and best hearts of Rome.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Soft! who comes here? A friend of Antony's.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Thus, Brutus, did my master bid me kneel:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Thus did Mark Antony bid me fall down;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: And, being prostrate, thus he bade me say:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Brutus is noble, wise, valiant, and honest;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Caesar was mighty, bold, royal, and loving:

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Say I love Brutus, and I honour him;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Say I fear'd Caesar, honour'd him and loved him.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: If Brutus will vouchsafe that Antony

speaker: Servant
text_entry: May safely come to him, and be resolved

speaker: Servant
text_entry: How Caesar hath deserved to lie in death,

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Mark Antony shall not love Caesar dead

speaker: Servant
text_entry: So well as Brutus living; but will follow

speaker: Servant
text_entry: The fortunes and affairs of noble Brutus

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Thorough the hazards of this untrod state

speaker: Servant
text_entry: With all true faith. So says my master Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy master is a wise and valiant Roman;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I never thought him worse.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Tell him, so please him come unto this place,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He shall be satisfied; and, by my honour,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Depart untouch'd.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I'll fetch him presently.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know that we shall have him well to friend.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I wish we may: but yet have I a mind

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That fears him much; and my misgiving still

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Falls shrewdly to the purpose.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But here comes Antony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter ANTONY

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Welcome, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O mighty Caesar! dost thou lie so low?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Are all thy conquests, glories, triumphs, spoils,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shrunk to this little measure? Fare thee well.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I know not, gentlemen, what you intend,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Who else must be let blood, who else is rank:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If I myself, there is no hour so fit

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: As Caesar's death hour, nor no instrument

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Of half that worth as those your swords, made rich

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With the most noble blood of all this world.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I do beseech ye, if you bear me hard,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Now, whilst your purpled hands do reek and smoke,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Fulfil your pleasure. Live a thousand years,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I shall not find myself so apt to die:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: No place will please me so, no mean of death,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: As here by Caesar, and by you cut off,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The choice and master spirits of this age.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Antony, beg not your death of us.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Though now we must appear bloody and cruel,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As, by our hands and this our present act,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You see we do, yet see you but our hands

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And this the bleeding business they have done:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our hearts you see not; they are pitiful;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And pity to the general wrong of Rome--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As fire drives out fire, so pity pity--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hath done this deed on Caesar. For your part,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To you our swords have leaden points, Mark Antony:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our arms, in strength of malice, and our hearts

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of brothers' temper, do receive you in

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With all kind love, good thoughts, and reverence.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Your voice shall be as strong as any man's

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In the disposing of new dignities.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Only be patient till we have appeased

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The multitude, beside themselves with fear,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And then we will deliver you the cause,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why I, that did love Caesar when I struck him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have thus proceeded.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I doubt not of your wisdom.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Let each man render me his bloody hand:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: First, Marcus Brutus, will I shake with you;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Next, Caius Cassius, do I take your hand;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Now, Decius Brutus, yours: now yours, Metellus;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yours, Cinna; and, my valiant Casca, yours;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Though last, not last in love, yours, good Trebonius.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Gentlemen all,--alas, what shall I say?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: My credit now stands on such slippery ground,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That one of two bad ways you must conceit me,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Either a coward or a flatterer.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That I did love thee, Caesar, O, 'tis true:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If then thy spirit look upon us now,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall it not grieve thee dearer than thy death,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To see thy thy Anthony making his peace,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shaking the bloody fingers of thy foes,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Most noble! in the presence of thy corse?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Had I as many eyes as thou hast wounds,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Weeping as fast as they stream forth thy blood,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It would become me better than to close

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In terms of friendship with thine enemies.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Pardon me, Julius! Here wast thou bay'd, brave hart;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here didst thou fall; and here thy hunters stand,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Sign'd in thy spoil, and crimson'd in thy lethe.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O world, thou wast the forest to this hart;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And this, indeed, O world, the heart of thee.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How like a deer, strucken by many princes,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Dost thou here lie!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mark Antony,--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Pardon me, Caius Cassius:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The enemies of Caesar shall say this;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then, in a friend, it is cold modesty.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I blame you not for praising Caesar so;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But what compact mean you to have with us?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Will you be prick'd in number of our friends;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Or shall we on, and not depend on you?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Therefore I took your hands, but was, indeed,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Sway'd from the point, by looking down on Caesar.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Friends am I with you all and love you all,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Upon this hope, that you shall give me reasons

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Why and wherein Caesar was dangerous.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Or else were this a savage spectacle:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our reasons are so full of good regard

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That were you, Antony, the son of Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You should be satisfied.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That's all I seek:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And am moreover suitor that I may

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Produce his body to the market-place;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And in the pulpit, as becomes a friend,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Speak in the order of his funeral.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You shall, Mark Antony.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, a word with you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Aside to BRUTUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You know not what you do: do not consent

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That Antony speak in his funeral:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Know you how much the people may be moved

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: By that which he will utter?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By your pardon;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will myself into the pulpit first,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And show the reason of our Caesar's death:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What Antony shall speak, I will protest

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He speaks by leave and by permission,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And that we are contented Caesar shall

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have all true rites and lawful ceremonies.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It shall advantage more than do us wrong.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I know not what may fall; I like it not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Mark Antony, here, take you Caesar's body.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You shall not in your funeral speech blame us,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But speak all good you can devise of Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And say you do't by our permission;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Else shall you not have any hand at all

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: About his funeral: and you shall speak

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In the same pulpit whereto I am going,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: After my speech is ended.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Be it so.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I do desire no more.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Prepare the body then, and follow us.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but ANTONY

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Thou art the ruins of the noblest man

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That ever lived in the tide of times.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Woe to the hand that shed this costly blood!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Over thy wounds now do I prophesy,--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which, like dumb mouths, do ope their ruby lips,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To beg the voice and utterance of my tongue--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: A curse shall light upon the limbs of men;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Domestic fury and fierce civil strife

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall cumber all the parts of Italy;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Blood and destruction shall be so in use

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And dreadful objects so familiar

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That mothers shall but smile when they behold

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Their infants quarter'd with the hands of war;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: All pity choked with custom of fell deeds:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Caesar's spirit, ranging for revenge,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With Ate by his side come hot from hell,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall in these confines with a monarch's voice

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Cry  'Havoc,' and let slip the dogs of war;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That this foul deed shall smell above the earth

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With carrion men, groaning for burial.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You serve Octavius Caesar, do you not?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I do, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Caesar did write for him to come to Rome.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He did receive his letters, and is coming;

speaker: Servant
text_entry: And bid me say to you by word of mouth--

speaker: Servant
text_entry: O Caesar!--

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Seeing the body

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Thy heart is big, get thee apart and weep.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Passion, I see, is catching; for mine eyes,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Seeing those beads of sorrow stand in thine,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Began to water. Is thy master coming?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He lies to-night within seven leagues of Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Post back with speed, and tell him what hath chanced:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here is a mourning Rome, a dangerous Rome,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: No Rome of safety for Octavius yet;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hie hence, and tell him so. Yet, stay awhile;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Thou shalt not back till I have borne this corse

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Into the market-place: there shall I try

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In my oration, how the people take

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The cruel issue of these bloody men;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: According to the which, thou shalt discourse

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To young Octavius of the state of things.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Lend me your hand.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt with CAESAR's body

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE II. The Forum.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS, and a throng of Citizens

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: We will be satisfied; let us be satisfied.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then follow me, and give me audience, friends.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cassius, go you into the other street,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And part the numbers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Those that will hear me speak, let 'em stay here;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Those that will follow Cassius, go with him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And public reasons shall be rendered

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of Caesar's death.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: I will hear Brutus speak.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: I will hear Cassius; and compare their reasons,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: When severally we hear them rendered.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Exit CASSIUS, with some of the Citizens. BRUTUS goes into the pulpit

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: The noble Brutus is ascended: silence!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be patient till the last.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Romans, countrymen, and lovers! hear me for my

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: cause, and be silent, that you may hear: believe me

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: for mine honour, and have respect to mine honour, that

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: you may believe: censure me in your wisdom, and

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: awake your senses, that you may the better judge.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If there be any in this assembly, any dear friend of

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar's, to him I say, that Brutus' love to Caesar

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: was no less than his. If then that friend demand

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: why Brutus rose against Caesar, this is my answer:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: --Not that I loved Caesar less, but that I loved

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Rome more. Had you rather Caesar were living and

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: die all slaves, than that Caesar were dead, to live

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: all free men? As Caesar loved me, I weep for him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: as he was fortunate, I rejoice at it; as he was

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: valiant, I honour him: but, as he was ambitious, I

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: slew him. There is tears for his love; joy for his

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: fortune; honour for his valour; and death for his

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: ambition. Who is here so base that would be a

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: bondman? If any, speak; for him have I offended.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Who is here so rude that would not be a Roman? If

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: any, speak; for him have I offended. Who is here so

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: vile that will not love his country? If any, speak;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: for him have I offended. I pause for a reply.

speaker: All
text_entry: None, Brutus, none.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then none have I offended. I have done no more to

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar than you shall do to Brutus. The question of

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: his death is enrolled in the Capitol; his glory not

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: extenuated, wherein he was worthy, nor his offences

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: enforced, for which he suffered death.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter ANTONY and others, with CAESAR's body

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Here comes his body, mourned by Mark Antony: who,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: though he had no hand in his death, shall receive

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: the benefit of his dying, a place in the

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: commonwealth; as which of you shall not? With this

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I depart,--that, as I slew my best lover for the

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: good of Rome, I have the same dagger for myself,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: when it shall please my country to need my death.

speaker: All
text_entry: Live, Brutus! live, live!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Bring him with triumph home unto his house.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Give him a statue with his ancestors.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Let him be Caesar.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Caesar's better parts

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Shall be crown'd in Brutus.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We'll bring him to his house

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: With shouts and clamours.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My countrymen,--

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Peace, silence! Brutus speaks.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Peace, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good countrymen, let me depart alone,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, for my sake, stay here with Antony:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do grace to Caesar's corpse, and grace his speech

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Tending to Caesar's glories; which Mark Antony,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By our permission, is allow'd to make.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do entreat you, not a man depart,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Save I alone, till Antony have spoke.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Stay, ho! and let us hear Mark Antony.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Let him go up into the public chair;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We'll hear him. Noble Antony, go up.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For Brutus' sake, I am beholding to you.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Goes into the pulpit

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: What does he say of Brutus?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He says, for Brutus' sake,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He finds himself beholding to us all.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: 'Twere best he speak no harm of Brutus here.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: This Caesar was a tyrant.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Nay, that's certain:

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We are blest that Rome is rid of him.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Peace! let us hear what Antony can say.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You gentle Romans,--

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: Peace, ho! let us hear him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The evil that men do lives after them;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The good is oft interred with their bones;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So let it be with Caesar. The noble Brutus

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hath told you Caesar was ambitious:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If it were so, it was a grievous fault,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And grievously hath Caesar answer'd it.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here, under leave of Brutus and the rest--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For Brutus is an honourable man;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So are they all, all honourable men--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Come I to speak in Caesar's funeral.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He was my friend, faithful and just to me:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But Brutus says he was ambitious;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Brutus is an honourable man.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He hath brought many captives home to Rome

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whose ransoms did the general coffers fill:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Did this in Caesar seem ambitious?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: When that the poor have cried, Caesar hath wept:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Ambition should be made of sterner stuff:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Brutus is an honourable man.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You all did see that on the Lupercal

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I thrice presented him a kingly crown,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which he did thrice refuse: was this ambition?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yet Brutus says he was ambitious;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, sure, he is an honourable man.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I speak not to disprove what Brutus spoke,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But here I am to speak what I do know.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You all did love him once, not without cause:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: What cause withholds you then, to mourn for him?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O judgment! thou art fled to brutish beasts,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And men have lost their reason. Bear with me;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: My heart is in the coffin there with Caesar,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And I must pause till it come back to me.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Methinks there is much reason in his sayings.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: If thou consider rightly of the matter,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Caesar has had great wrong.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Has he, masters?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: I fear there will a worse come in his place.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Mark'd ye his words? He would not take the crown;

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Therefore 'tis certain he was not ambitious.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: If it be found so, some will dear abide it.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Poor soul! his eyes are red as fire with weeping.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: There's not a nobler man in Rome than Antony.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Now mark him, he begins again to speak.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But yesterday the word of Caesar might

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Have stood against the world; now lies he there.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And none so poor to do him reverence.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O masters, if I were disposed to stir

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Your hearts and minds to mutiny and rage,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I should do Brutus wrong, and Cassius wrong,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Who, you all know, are honourable men:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I will not do them wrong; I rather choose

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To wrong the dead, to wrong myself and you,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Than I will wrong such honourable men.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But here's a parchment with the seal of Caesar;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I found it in his closet, 'tis his will:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Let but the commons hear this testament--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which, pardon me, I do not mean to read--

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And they would go and kiss dead Caesar's wounds

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And dip their napkins in his sacred blood,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yea, beg a hair of him for memory,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, dying, mention it within their wills,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Bequeathing it as a rich legacy

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Unto their issue.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: We'll hear the will: read it, Mark Antony.

speaker: All
text_entry: The will, the will! we will hear Caesar's will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Have patience, gentle friends, I must not read it;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It is not meet you know how Caesar loved you.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You are not wood, you are not stones, but men;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, being men, bearing the will of Caesar,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It will inflame you, it will make you mad:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: 'Tis good you know not that you are his heirs;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For, if you should, O, what would come of it!

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Read the will; we'll hear it, Antony;

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: You shall read us the will, Caesar's will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Will you be patient? will you stay awhile?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I have o'ershot myself to tell you of it:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I fear I wrong the honourable men

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whose daggers have stabb'd Caesar; I do fear it.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: They were traitors: honourable men!

speaker: All
text_entry: The will! the testament!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: They were villains, murderers: the will! read the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You will compel me, then, to read the will?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then make a ring about the corpse of Caesar,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And let me show you him that made the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Shall I descend? and will you give me leave?

speaker: Several Citizens
text_entry: Come down.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Descend.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: You shall have leave.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: ANTONY comes down

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: A ring; stand round.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Stand from the hearse, stand from the body.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Room for Antony, most noble Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Nay, press not so upon me; stand far off.

speaker: Several Citizens
text_entry: Stand back; room; bear back.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If you have tears, prepare to shed them now.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You all do know this mantle: I remember

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The first time ever Caesar put it on;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: 'Twas on a summer's evening, in his tent,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That day he overcame the Nervii:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Look, in this place ran Cassius' dagger through:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: See what a rent the envious Casca made:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Through this the well-beloved Brutus stabb'd;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And as he pluck'd his cursed steel away,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Mark how the blood of Caesar follow'd it,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: As rushing out of doors, to be resolved

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: If Brutus so unkindly knock'd, or no;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For Brutus, as you know, was Caesar's angel:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Judge, O you gods, how dearly Caesar loved him!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: This was the most unkindest cut of all;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For when the noble Caesar saw him stab,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Ingratitude, more strong than traitors' arms,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Quite vanquish'd him: then burst his mighty heart;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, in his mantle muffling up his face,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Even at the base of Pompey's statua,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which all the while ran blood, great Caesar fell.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O, what a fall was there, my countrymen!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then I, and you, and all of us fell down,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whilst bloody treason flourish'd over us.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: O, now you weep; and, I perceive, you feel

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The dint of pity: these are gracious drops.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Kind souls, what, weep you when you but behold

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Our Caesar's vesture wounded? Look you here,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here is himself, marr'd, as you see, with traitors.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: O piteous spectacle!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: O noble Caesar!

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: O woful day!

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: O traitors, villains!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: O most bloody sight!

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: We will be revenged.

speaker: All
text_entry: Revenge! About! Seek! Burn! Fire! Kill! Slay!

speaker: All
text_entry: Let not a traitor live!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Stay, countrymen.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Peace there! hear the noble Antony.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: We'll hear him, we'll follow him, we'll die with him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Good friends, sweet friends, let me not stir you up

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To such a sudden flood of mutiny.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: They that have done this deed are honourable:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: What private griefs they have, alas, I know not,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That made them do it: they are wise and honourable,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And will, no doubt, with reasons answer you.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I come not, friends, to steal away your hearts:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I am no orator, as Brutus is;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But, as you know me all, a plain blunt man,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That love my friend; and that they know full well

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: That gave me public leave to speak of him:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: For I have neither wit, nor words, nor worth,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Action, nor utterance, nor the power of speech,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To stir men's blood: I only speak right on;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I tell you that which you yourselves do know;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Show you sweet Caesar's wounds, poor poor dumb mouths,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And bid them speak for me: but were I Brutus,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And Brutus Antony, there were an Antony

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Would ruffle up your spirits and put a tongue

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In every wound of Caesar that should move

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The stones of Rome to rise and mutiny.

speaker: All
text_entry: We'll mutiny.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We'll burn the house of Brutus.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Away, then! come, seek the conspirators.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Yet hear me, countrymen; yet hear me speak.

speaker: All
text_entry: Peace, ho! Hear Antony. Most noble Antony!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Why, friends, you go to do you know not what:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Wherein hath Caesar thus deserved your loves?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Alas, you know not: I must tell you then:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You have forgot the will I told you of.

speaker: All
text_entry: Most true. The will! Let's stay and hear the will.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here is the will, and under Caesar's seal.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To every Roman citizen he gives,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To every several man, seventy-five drachmas.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Most noble Caesar! We'll revenge his death.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: O royal Caesar!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hear me with patience.

speaker: All
text_entry: Peace, ho!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Moreover, he hath left you all his walks,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: His private arbours and new-planted orchards,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: On this side Tiber; he hath left them you,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And to your heirs for ever, common pleasures,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To walk abroad, and recreate yourselves.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Here was a Caesar! when comes such another?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Never, never. Come, away, away!

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: We'll burn his body in the holy place,

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: And with the brands fire the traitors' houses.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Take up the body.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Go fetch fire.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Pluck down benches.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Pluck down forms, windows, any thing.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Exeunt Citizens with the body

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Now let it work. Mischief, thou art afoot,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Take thou what course thou wilt!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How now, fellow!

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Sir, Octavius is already come to Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Where is he?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: He and Lepidus are at Caesar's house.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And thither will I straight to visit him:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He comes upon a wish. Fortune is merry,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And in this mood will give us any thing.

speaker: Servant
text_entry: I heard him say, Brutus and Cassius

speaker: Servant
text_entry: Are rid like madmen through the gates of Rome.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Belike they had some notice of the people,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How I had moved them. Bring me to Octavius.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE III. A street.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter CINNA the poet

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: I dreamt to-night that I did feast with Caesar,

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: And things unlucky charge my fantasy:

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: I have no will to wander forth of doors,

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: Yet something leads me forth.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: Enter Citizens

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: What is your name?

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Whither are you going?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Where do you dwell?

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Are you a married man or a bachelor?

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Answer every man directly.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Ay, and briefly.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Ay, and wisely.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Ay, and truly, you were best.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: What is my name? Whither am I going? Where do I

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: dwell? Am I a married man or a bachelor? Then, to

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: answer every man directly and briefly, wisely and

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: truly: wisely I say, I am a bachelor.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: That's as much as to say, they are fools that marry:

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: you'll bear me a bang for that, I fear. Proceed; directly.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: Directly, I am going to Caesar's funeral.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: As a friend or an enemy?

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: As a friend.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: That matter is answered directly.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: For your dwelling,--briefly.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: Briefly, I dwell by the Capitol.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Your name, sir, truly.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: Truly, my name is Cinna.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Tear him to pieces; he's a conspirator.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: I am Cinna the poet, I am Cinna the poet.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: Tear him for his bad verses, tear him for his bad verses.

speaker: CINNA THE POET
text_entry: I am not Cinna the conspirator.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: It is no matter, his name's Cinna; pluck but his

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: name out of his heart, and turn him going.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Tear him, tear him! Come, brands ho! fire-brands:

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: to Brutus', to Cassius'; burn all: some to Decius'

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: house, and some to Casca's; some to Ligarius': away, go!

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: ACT IV

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: SCENE I. A house in Rome.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: ANTONY, OCTAVIUS, and LEPIDUS, seated at a table

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: These many, then, shall die; their names are prick'd.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Your brother too must die; consent you, Lepidus?

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: I do consent--

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Prick him down, Antony.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: Upon condition Publius shall not live,

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: Who is your sister's son, Mark Antony.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He shall not live; look, with a spot I damn him.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But, Lepidus, go you to Caesar's house;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Fetch the will hither, and we shall determine

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How to cut off some charge in legacies.

speaker: LEPIDUS
text_entry: What, shall I find you here?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Or here, or at the Capitol.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Exit LEPIDUS

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: This is a slight unmeritable man,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Meet to be sent on errands: is it fit,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: The three-fold world divided, he should stand

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: One of the three to share it?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: So you thought him;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: And took his voice who should be prick'd to die,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: In our black sentence and proscription.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Octavius, I have seen more days than you:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And though we lay these honours on this man,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To ease ourselves of divers slanderous loads,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He shall but bear them as the ass bears gold,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To groan and sweat under the business,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Either led or driven, as we point the way;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And having brought our treasure where we will,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Then take we down his load, and turn him off,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Like to the empty ass, to shake his ears,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And graze in commons.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: You may do your will;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: But he's a tried and valiant soldier.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So is my horse, Octavius; and for that

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: I do appoint him store of provender:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: It is a creature that I teach to fight,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To wind, to stop, to run directly on,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: His corporal motion govern'd by my spirit.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And, in some taste, is Lepidus but so;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He must be taught and train'd and bid go forth;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: A barren-spirited fellow; one that feeds

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: On abjects, orts and imitations,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Which, out of use and staled by other men,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Begin his fashion: do not talk of him,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But as a property. And now, Octavius,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Listen great things:--Brutus and Cassius

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Are levying powers: we must straight make head:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Therefore let our alliance be combined,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Our best friends made, our means stretch'd

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And let us presently go sit in council,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How covert matters may be best disclosed,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And open perils surest answered.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Let us do so: for we are at the stake,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: And bay'd about with many enemies;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: And some that smile have in their hearts, I fear,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Millions of mischiefs.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: SCENE II. Camp near Sardis. Before BRUTUS's tent.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Drum. Enter BRUTUS, LUCILIUS, LUCIUS, and Soldiers; TITINIUS and PINDARUS meeting them

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Stand, ho!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Give the word, ho! and stand.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What now, Lucilius! is Cassius near?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: He is at hand; and Pindarus is come

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: To do you salutation from his master.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He greets me well. Your master, Pindarus,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In his own change, or by ill officers,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hath given me some worthy cause to wish

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Things done, undone: but, if he be at hand,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall be satisfied.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: I do not doubt

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: But that my noble master will appear

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Such as he is, full of regard and honour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is not doubted. A word, Lucilius;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How he received you, let me be resolved.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: With courtesy and with respect enough;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: But not with such familiar instances,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Nor with such free and friendly conference,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: As he hath used of old.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thou hast described

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A hot friend cooling: ever note, Lucilius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When love begins to sicken and decay,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It useth an enforced ceremony.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There are no tricks in plain and simple faith;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But hollow men, like horses hot at hand,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Make gallant show and promise of their mettle;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But when they should endure the bloody spur,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They fall their crests, and, like deceitful jades,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sink in the trial. Comes his army on?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: They mean this night in Sardis to be quarter'd;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: The greater part, the horse in general,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Are come with Cassius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hark! he is arrived.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Low march within

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: March gently on to meet him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter CASSIUS and his powers

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stand, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Stand, ho! Speak the word along.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Stand!

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: Stand!

speaker: Third Soldier
text_entry: Stand!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Most noble brother, you have done me wrong.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Judge me, you gods! wrong I mine enemies?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, if not so, how should I wrong a brother?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, this sober form of yours hides wrongs;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And when you do them--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cassius, be content.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Speak your griefs softly: I do know you well.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Before the eyes of both our armies here,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which should perceive nothing but love from us,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let us not wrangle: bid them move away;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then in my tent, Cassius, enlarge your griefs,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And I will give you audience.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Pindarus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Bid our commanders lead their charges off

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A little from this ground.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucilius, do you the like; and let no man

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come to our tent till we have done our conference.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let Lucius and Titinius guard our door.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Brutus's tent.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS and CASSIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That you have wrong'd me doth appear in this:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You have condemn'd and noted Lucius Pella

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For taking bribes here of the Sardians;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Wherein my letters, praying on his side,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Because I knew the man, were slighted off.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You wronged yourself to write in such a case.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In such a time as this it is not meet

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That every nice offence should bear his comment.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me tell you, Cassius, you yourself

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Are much condemn'd to have an itching palm;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To sell and mart your offices for gold

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To undeservers.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I an itching palm!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You know that you are Brutus that speak this,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Or, by the gods, this speech were else your last.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The name of Cassius honours this corruption,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And chastisement doth therefore hide his head.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Chastisement!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Remember March, the ides of March remember:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Did not great Julius bleed for justice' sake?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What villain touch'd his body, that did stab,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And not for justice? What, shall one of us

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That struck the foremost man of all this world

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But for supporting robbers, shall we now

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Contaminate our fingers with base bribes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And sell the mighty space of our large honours

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For so much trash as may be grasped thus?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I had rather be a dog, and bay the moon,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than such a Roman.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Brutus, bay not me;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I'll not endure it: you forget yourself,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To hedge me in; I am a soldier, I,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Older in practise, abler than yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To make conditions.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go to; you are not, Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I am.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I say you are not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Urge me no more, I shall forget myself;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have mind upon your health, tempt me no further.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Away, slight man!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is't possible?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hear me, for I will speak.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Must I give way and room to your rash choler?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O ye gods, ye gods! must I endure all this?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: All this! ay, more: fret till your proud heart break;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go show your slaves how choleric you are,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And make your bondmen tremble. Must I budge?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Must I observe you? must I stand and crouch

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Under your testy humour? By the gods

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You shall digest the venom of your spleen,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Though it do split you; for, from this day forth,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll use you for my mirth, yea, for my laughter,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When you are waspish.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Is it come to this?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You say you are a better soldier:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let it appear so; make your vaunting true,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And it shall please me well: for mine own part,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall be glad to learn of noble men.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You wrong me every way; you wrong me, Brutus;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I said, an elder soldier, not a better:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Did I say 'better'?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If you did, I care not.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When Caesar lived, he durst not thus have moved me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Peace, peace! you durst not so have tempted him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I durst not!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What, durst not tempt him!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For your life you durst not!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Do not presume too much upon my love;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I may do that I shall be sorry for.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You have done that you should be sorry for.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is no terror, Cassius, in your threats,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For I am arm'd so strong in honesty

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That they pass by me as the idle wind,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which I respect not. I did send to you

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For certain sums of gold, which you denied me:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For I can raise no money by vile means:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By heaven, I had rather coin my heart,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And drop my blood for drachmas, than to wring

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: From the hard hands of peasants their vile trash

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By any indirection: I did send

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To you for gold to pay my legions,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which you denied me: was that done like Cassius?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Should I have answer'd Caius Cassius so?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When Marcus Brutus grows so covetous,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To lock such rascal counters from his friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be ready, gods, with all your thunderbolts;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Dash him to pieces!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I denied you not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You did.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I did not: he was but a fool that brought

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My answer back. Brutus hath rived my heart:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A friend should bear his friend's infirmities,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But Brutus makes mine greater than they are.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do not, till you practise them on me.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You love me not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I do not like your faults.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A friendly eye could never see such faults.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A flatterer's would not, though they do appear

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As huge as high Olympus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come, Antony, and young Octavius, come,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Revenge yourselves alone on Cassius,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For Cassius is aweary of the world;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Hated by one he loves; braved by his brother;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cheque'd like a bondman; all his faults observed,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Set in a note-book, learn'd, and conn'd by rote,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To cast into my teeth. O, I could weep

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My spirit from mine eyes! There is my dagger,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And here my naked breast; within, a heart

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Dearer than Plutus' mine, richer than gold:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If that thou be'st a Roman, take it forth;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I, that denied thee gold, will give my heart:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Strike, as thou didst at Caesar; for, I know,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When thou didst hate him worst, thou lovedst him better

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Than ever thou lovedst Cassius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sheathe your dagger:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be angry when you will, it shall have scope;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do what you will, dishonour shall be humour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Cassius, you are yoked with a lamb

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That carries anger as the flint bears fire;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Who, much enforced, shows a hasty spark,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And straight is cold again.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Hath Cassius lived

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To be but mirth and laughter to his Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When grief, and blood ill-temper'd, vexeth him?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When I spoke that, I was ill-temper'd too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Do you confess so much? Give me your hand.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And my heart too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O Brutus!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What's the matter?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Have not you love enough to bear with me,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: When that rash humour which my mother gave me

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Makes me forgetful?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Yes, Cassius; and, from henceforth,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When you are over-earnest with your Brutus,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He'll think your mother chides, and leave you so.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: [Within]  Let me go in to see the generals;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: There is some grudge between 'em, 'tis not meet

speaker: Poet
text_entry: They be alone.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: [Within]  You shall not come to them.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: [Within]  Nothing but death shall stay me.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Enter Poet, followed by LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, and LUCIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: How now! what's the matter?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: For shame, you generals! what do you mean?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Love, and be friends, as two such men should be;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: For I have seen more years, I'm sure, than ye.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ha, ha! how vilely doth this cynic rhyme!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get you hence, sirrah; saucy fellow, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Bear with him, Brutus; 'tis his fashion.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll know his humour, when he knows his time:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What should the wars do with these jigging fools?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Companion, hence!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Away, away, be gone.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exit Poet

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucilius and Titinius, bid the commanders

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Prepare to lodge their companies to-night.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And come yourselves, and bring Messala with you

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Immediately to us.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCILIUS and TITINIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius, a bowl of wine!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I did not think you could have been so angry.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Cassius, I am sick of many griefs.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of your philosophy you make no use,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If you give place to accidental evils.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No man bears sorrow better. Portia is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Ha! Portia!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: She is dead.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: How 'scaped I killing when I cross'd you so?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O insupportable and touching loss!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon what sickness?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Impatient of my absence,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And grief that young Octavius with Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Have made themselves so strong:--for with her death

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That tidings came;--with this she fell distract,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, her attendants absent, swallow'd fire.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And died so?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even so.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O ye immortal gods!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS, with wine and taper

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Speak no more of her. Give me a bowl of wine.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In this I bury all unkindness, Cassius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My heart is thirsty for that noble pledge.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Fill, Lucius, till the wine o'erswell the cup;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I cannot drink too much of Brutus' love.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come in, Titinius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter TITINIUS, with MESSALA

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Welcome, good Messala.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now sit we close about this taper here,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And call in question our necessities.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Portia, art thou gone?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No more, I pray you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Messala, I have here received letters,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That young Octavius and Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come down upon us with a mighty power,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Bending their expedition toward Philippi.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Myself have letters of the selfsame tenor.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With what addition?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: That by proscription and bills of outlawry,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Octavius, Antony, and Lepidus,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Have put to death an hundred senators.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Therein our letters do not well agree;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Mine speak of seventy senators that died

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By their proscriptions, Cicero being one.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Cicero one!

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Cicero is dead,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: And by that order of proscription.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Had you your letters from your wife, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Nor nothing in your letters writ of her?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nothing, Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: That, methinks, is strange.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why ask you? hear you aught of her in yours?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: No, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now, as you are a Roman, tell me true.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Then like a Roman bear the truth I tell:

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: For certain she is dead, and by strange manner.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, farewell, Portia. We must die, Messala:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With meditating that she must die once,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have the patience to endure it now.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Even so great men great losses should endure.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I have as much of this in art as you,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But yet my nature could not bear it so.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Well, to our work alive. What do you think

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of marching to Philippi presently?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I do not think it good.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Your reason?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This it is:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: 'Tis better that the enemy seek us:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: So shall he waste his means, weary his soldiers,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Doing himself offence; whilst we, lying still,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Are full of rest, defense, and nimbleness.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good reasons must, of force, give place to better.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The people 'twixt Philippi and this ground

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do stand but in a forced affection;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For they have grudged us contribution:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The enemy, marching along by them,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By them shall make a fuller number up,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come on refresh'd, new-added, and encouraged;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: From which advantage shall we cut him off,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If at Philippi we do face him there,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: These people at our back.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Hear me, good brother.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Under your pardon. You must note beside,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That we have tried the utmost of our friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our legions are brim-full, our cause is ripe:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The enemy increaseth every day;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We, at the height, are ready to decline.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is a tide in the affairs of men,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which, taken at the flood, leads on to fortune;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Omitted, all the voyage of their life

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is bound in shallows and in miseries.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: On such a full sea are we now afloat;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And we must take the current when it serves,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Or lose our ventures.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then, with your will, go on;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: We'll along ourselves, and meet them at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The deep of night is crept upon our talk,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And nature must obey necessity;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which we will niggard with a little rest.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: There is no more to say?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: No more. Good night:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Early to-morrow will we rise, and hence.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My gown.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell, good Messala:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good night, Titinius. Noble, noble Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good night, and good repose.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O my dear brother!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This was an ill beginning of the night:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Never come such division 'tween our souls!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let it not, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Every thing is well.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Good night, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good night, good brother.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Good night, Lord Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell, every one.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS, with the gown

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give me the gown. Where is thy instrument?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Here in the tent.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What, thou speak'st drowsily?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Poor knave, I blame thee not; thou art o'er-watch'd.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Call Claudius and some other of my men:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll have them sleep on cushions in my tent.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Varro and Claudius!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Enter VARRO and CLAUDIUS

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: Calls my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I pray you, sirs, lie in my tent and sleep;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It may be I shall raise you by and by

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: On business to my brother Cassius.

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: So please you, we will stand and watch your pleasure.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will not have it so: lie down, good sirs;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It may be I shall otherwise bethink me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Look, Lucius, here's the book I sought for so;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I put it in the pocket of my gown.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: VARRO and CLAUDIUS lie down

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I was sure your lordship did not give it me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Bear with me, good boy, I am much forgetful.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Canst thou hold up thy heavy eyes awhile,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And touch thy instrument a strain or two?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Ay, my lord, an't please you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It does, my boy:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I trouble thee too much, but thou art willing.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: It is my duty, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I should not urge thy duty past thy might;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know young bloods look for a time of rest.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I have slept, my lord, already.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It was well done; and thou shalt sleep again;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will not hold thee long: if I do live,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will be good to thee.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Music, and a song

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: This is a sleepy tune. O murderous slumber,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lay'st thou thy leaden mace upon my boy,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That plays thee music? Gentle knave, good night;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I will not do thee so much wrong to wake thee:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If thou dost nod, thou break'st thy instrument;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I'll take it from thee; and, good boy, good night.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me see, let me see; is not the leaf turn'd down

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where I left reading? Here it is, I think.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter the Ghost of CAESAR

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How ill this taper burns! Ha! who comes here?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I think it is the weakness of mine eyes

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That shapes this monstrous apparition.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It comes upon me. Art thou any thing?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Art thou some god, some angel, or some devil,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That makest my blood cold and my hair to stare?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Speak to me what thou art.

speaker: GHOST
text_entry: Thy evil spirit, Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why comest thou?

speaker: GHOST
text_entry: To tell thee thou shalt see me at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Well; then I shall see thee again?

speaker: GHOST
text_entry: Ay, at Philippi.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, I will see thee at Philippi, then.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit Ghost

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now I have taken heart thou vanishest:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ill spirit, I would hold more talk with thee.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Boy, Lucius! Varro! Claudius! Sirs, awake! Claudius!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The strings, my lord, are false.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He thinks he still is at his instrument.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius, awake!

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Didst thou dream, Lucius, that thou so criedst out?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: My lord, I do not know that I did cry.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Yes, that thou didst: didst thou see any thing?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Nothing, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sleep again, Lucius. Sirrah Claudius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To VARRO

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fellow thou, awake!

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: My lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why did you so cry out, sirs, in your sleep?

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Did we, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ay: saw you any thing?

speaker: VARRO
text_entry: No, my lord, I saw nothing.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Nor I, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Go and commend me to my brother Cassius;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Bid him set on his powers betimes before,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And we will follow.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: It shall be done, my lord.
