speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: ACT V

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. The plains of Philippi.

speaker: CLAUDIUS
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Now, Antony, our hopes are answered:

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: You said the enemy would not come down,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: But keep the hills and upper regions;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: It proves not so: their battles are at hand;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: They mean to warn us at Philippi here,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Answering before we do demand of them.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Tut, I am in their bosoms, and I know

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Wherefore they do it: they could be content

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To visit other places; and come down

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: With fearful bravery, thinking by this face

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: To fasten in our thoughts that they have courage;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: But 'tis not so.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter a Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Prepare you, generals:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The enemy comes on in gallant show;

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Their bloody sign of battle is hung out,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: And something to be done immediately.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Octavius, lead your battle softly on,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Upon the left hand of the even field.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Upon the right hand I; keep thou the left.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: I do not cross you; but I will do so.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: March

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Drum. Enter BRUTUS, CASSIUS, and their Army; LUCILIUS, TITINIUS, MESSALA, and others

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They stand, and would have parley.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stand fast, Titinius: we must out and talk.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Mark Antony, shall we give sign of battle?

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: No, Caesar, we will answer on their charge.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Make forth; the generals would have some words.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Stir not until the signal.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Words before blows: is it so, countrymen?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Not that we love words better, as you do.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good words are better than bad strokes, Octavius.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: In your bad strokes, Brutus, you give good words:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Witness the hole you made in Caesar's heart,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Crying 'Long live! hail, Caesar!'

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Antony,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The posture of your blows are yet unknown;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But for your words, they rob the Hybla bees,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And leave them honeyless.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Not stingless too.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, yes, and soundless too;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For you have stol'n their buzzing, Antony,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And very wisely threat before you sting.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Villains, you did not so, when your vile daggers

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Hack'd one another in the sides of Caesar:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: You show'd your teeth like apes, and fawn'd like hounds,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And bow'd like bondmen, kissing Caesar's feet;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Whilst damned Casca, like a cur, behind

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Struck Caesar on the neck. O you flatterers!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Flatterers! Now, Brutus, thank yourself:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This tongue had not offended so to-day,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If Cassius might have ruled.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Come, come, the cause: if arguing make us sweat,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: The proof of it will turn to redder drops. Look;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: I draw a sword against conspirators;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: When think you that the sword goes up again?

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Never, till Caesar's three and thirty wounds

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Be well avenged; or till another Caesar

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Have added slaughter to the sword of traitors.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar, thou canst not die by traitors' hands,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Unless thou bring'st them with thee.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: So I hope;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: I was not born to die on Brutus' sword.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, if thou wert the noblest of thy strain,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Young man, thou couldst not die more honourable.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A peevish schoolboy, worthless of such honour,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Join'd with a masker and a reveller!

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Old Cassius still!

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Come, Antony, away!

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Defiance, traitors, hurl we in your teeth:

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: If you dare fight to-day, come to the field;

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: If not, when you have stomachs.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, and their army

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Why, now, blow wind, swell billow and swim bark!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The storm is up, and all is on the hazard.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ho, Lucilius! hark, a word with you.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: [Standing forth] My lord?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: BRUTUS and LUCILIUS converse apart

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Messala!

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: [Standing forth]  What says my general?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Messala,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This is my birth-day; as this very day

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Was Cassius born. Give me thy hand, Messala:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Be thou my witness that against my will,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As Pompey was, am I compell'd to set

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Upon one battle all our liberties.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You know that I held Epicurus strong

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And his opinion: now I change my mind,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And partly credit things that do presage.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Coming from Sardis, on our former ensign

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Two mighty eagles fell, and there they perch'd,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Gorging and feeding from our soldiers' hands;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Who to Philippi here consorted us:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This morning are they fled away and gone;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And in their steads do ravens, crows and kites,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Fly o'er our heads and downward look on us,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As we were sickly prey: their shadows seem

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A canopy most fatal, under which

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Our army lies, ready to give up the ghost.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Believe not so.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I but believe it partly;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For I am fresh of spirit and resolved

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To meet all perils very constantly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even so, Lucilius.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now, most noble Brutus,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The gods to-day stand friendly, that we may,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Lovers in peace, lead on our days to age!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But since the affairs of men rest still incertain,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let's reason with the worst that may befall.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If we do lose this battle, then is this

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The very last time we shall speak together:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What are you then determined to do?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even by the rule of that philosophy

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By which I did blame Cato for the death

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which he did give himself, I know not how,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But I do find it cowardly and vile,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For fear of what might fall, so to prevent

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The time of life: arming myself with patience

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To stay the providence of some high powers

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That govern us below.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then, if we lose this battle,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You are contented to be led in triumph

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thorough the streets of Rome?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, Cassius, no: think not, thou noble Roman,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That ever Brutus will go bound to Rome;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He bears too great a mind. But this same day

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Must end that work the ides of March begun;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And whether we shall meet again I know not.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Therefore our everlasting farewell take:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Cassius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If we do meet again, why, we shall smile;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If not, why then, this parting was well made.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For ever, and for ever, farewell, Brutus!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If we do meet again, we'll smile indeed;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If not, 'tis true this parting was well made.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, then, lead on. O, that a man might know

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The end of this day's business ere it come!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But it sufficeth that the day will end,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And then the end is known. Come, ho! away!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE II. The same. The field of battle.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alarum. Enter BRUTUS and MESSALA

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ride, ride, Messala, ride, and give these bills

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Unto the legions on the other side.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Loud alarum

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let them set on at once; for I perceive

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But cold demeanor in Octavius' wing,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And sudden push gives them the overthrow.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ride, ride, Messala: let them all come down.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE III. Another part of the field.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alarums. Enter CASSIUS and TITINIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O, look, Titinius, look, the villains fly!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Myself have to mine own turn'd enemy:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This ensign here of mine was turning back;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I slew the coward, and did take it from him.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: O Cassius, Brutus gave the word too early;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Who, having some advantage on Octavius,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Took it too eagerly: his soldiers fell to spoil,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Whilst we by Antony are all enclosed.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Enter PINDARUS

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Fly further off, my lord, fly further off;

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Mark Antony is in your tents, my lord

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Fly, therefore, noble Cassius, fly far off.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This hill is far enough. Look, look, Titinius;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Are those my tents where I perceive the fire?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: They are, my lord.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Titinius, if thou lovest me,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mount thou my horse, and hide thy spurs in him,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Till he have brought thee up to yonder troops,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And here again; that I may rest assured

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Whether yond troops are friend or enemy.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: I will be here again, even with a thought.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Go, Pindarus, get higher on that hill;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My sight was ever thick; regard Titinius,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And tell me what thou notest about the field.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: PINDARUS ascends the hill

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This day I breathed first: time is come round,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And where I did begin, there shall I end;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: My life is run his compass. Sirrah, what news?

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: [Above]  O my lord!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What news?

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: [Above]  Titinius is enclosed round about

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: With horsemen, that make to him on the spur;

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Yet he spurs on. Now they are almost on him.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Now, Titinius! Now some light. O, he lights too.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: He's ta'en.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Shout

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: And, hark! they shout for joy.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come down, behold no more.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: O, coward that I am, to live so long,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: To see my best friend ta'en before my face!

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: PINDARUS descends

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Come hither, sirrah:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: In Parthia did I take thee prisoner;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And then I swore thee, saving of thy life,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That whatsoever I did bid thee do,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Thou shouldst attempt it. Come now, keep thine oath;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Now be a freeman: and with this good sword,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: That ran through Caesar's bowels, search this bosom.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Stand not to answer: here, take thou the hilts;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And, when my face is cover'd, as 'tis now,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Guide thou the sword.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: PINDARUS stabs him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Caesar, thou art revenged,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Even with the sword that kill'd thee.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Dies

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: So, I am free; yet would not so have been,

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Durst I have done my will. O Cassius,

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Far from this country Pindarus shall run,

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Where never Roman shall take note of him.

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: PINDARUS
text_entry: Re-enter TITINIUS with MESSALA

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: It is but change, Titinius; for Octavius

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Is overthrown by noble Brutus' power,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: As Cassius' legions are by Antony.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: These tidings will well comfort Cassius.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Where did you leave him?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: All disconsolate,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: With Pindarus his bondman, on this hill.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Is not that he t hat lies upon the ground?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: He lies not like the living. O my heart!

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Is not that he?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: No, this was he, Messala,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: But Cassius is no more. O setting sun,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: As in thy red rays thou dost sink to-night,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: So in his red blood Cassius' day is set;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: The sun of Rome is set! Our day is gone;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Clouds, dews, and dangers come; our deeds are done!

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Mistrust of my success hath done this deed.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Mistrust of good success hath done this deed.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: O hateful error, melancholy's child,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Why dost thou show to the apt thoughts of men

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: The things that are not? O error, soon conceived,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Thou never comest unto a happy birth,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: But kill'st the mother that engender'd thee!

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: What, Pindarus! where art thou, Pindarus?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Seek him, Titinius, whilst I go to meet

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: The noble Brutus, thrusting this report

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Into his ears; I may say, thrusting it;

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: For piercing steel and darts envenomed

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Shall be as welcome to the ears of Brutus

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: As tidings of this sight.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Hie you, Messala,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: And I will seek for Pindarus the while.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Exit MESSALA

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Why didst thou send me forth, brave Cassius?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Did I not meet thy friends? and did not they

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Put on my brows this wreath of victory,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: And bid me give it thee? Didst thou not hear their shouts?

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Alas, thou hast misconstrued every thing!

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: But, hold thee, take this garland on thy brow;

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Thy Brutus bid me give it thee, and I

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Will do his bidding. Brutus, come apace,

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: And see how I regarded Caius Cassius.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: By your leave, gods:--this is a Roman's part

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Come, Cassius' sword, and find Titinius' heart.

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Kills himself

speaker: TITINIUS
text_entry: Alarum. Re-enter MESSALA, with BRUTUS, CATO, STRATO, VOLUMNIUS, and LUCILIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where, where, Messala, doth his body lie?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Lo, yonder, and Titinius mourning it.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Titinius' face is upward.

speaker: CATO
text_entry: He is slain.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O Julius Caesar, thou art mighty yet!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy spirit walks abroad and turns our swords

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: In our own proper entrails.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Low alarums

speaker: CATO
text_entry: Brave Titinius!

speaker: CATO
text_entry: Look, whether he have not crown'd dead Cassius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Are yet two Romans living such as these?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The last of all the Romans, fare thee well!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is impossible that ever Rome

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Should breed thy fellow. Friends, I owe more tears

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To this dead man than you shall see me pay.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall find time, Cassius, I shall find time.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come, therefore, and to Thasos send his body:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: His funerals shall not be in our camp,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lest it discomfort us. Lucilius, come;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And come, young Cato; let us to the field.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Labeo and Flavius, set our battles on:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Tis three o'clock; and, Romans, yet ere night

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We shall try fortune in a second fight.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. Another part of the field.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alarum. Enter fighting, Soldiers of both armies; then BRUTUS, CATO, LUCILIUS, and others

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Yet, countrymen, O, yet hold up your heads!

speaker: CATO
text_entry: What bastard doth not? Who will go with me?

speaker: CATO
text_entry: I will proclaim my name about the field:

speaker: CATO
text_entry: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!

speaker: CATO
text_entry: A foe to tyrants, and my country's friend;

speaker: CATO
text_entry: I am the son of Marcus Cato, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And I am Brutus, Marcus Brutus, I;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Brutus, my country's friend; know me for Brutus!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: O young and noble Cato, art thou down?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Why, now thou diest as bravely as Titinius;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: And mayst be honour'd, being Cato's son.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Yield, or thou diest.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Only I yield to die:

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: There is so much that thou wilt kill me straight;

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Offering money

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Kill Brutus, and be honour'd in his death.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: We must not. A noble prisoner!

speaker: Second Soldier
text_entry: Room, ho! Tell Antony, Brutus is ta'en.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: I'll tell the news. Here comes the general.

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Enter ANTONY

speaker: First Soldier
text_entry: Brutus is ta'en, Brutus is ta'en, my lord.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Where is he?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Safe, Antony; Brutus is safe enough:

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: I dare assure thee that no enemy

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Shall ever take alive the noble Brutus:

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: The gods defend him from so great a shame!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: When you do find him, or alive or dead,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: He will be found like Brutus, like himself.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: This is not Brutus, friend; but, I assure you,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: A prize no less in worth: keep this man safe;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Give him all kindness: I had rather have

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Such men my friends than enemies. Go on,

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And see whether Brutus be alive or dead;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And bring us word unto Octavius' tent

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: How every thing is chanced.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: SCENE V. Another part of the field.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS, DARDANIUS, CLITUS, STRATO, and VOLUMNIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come, poor remains of friends, rest on this rock.

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: Statilius show'd the torch-light, but, my lord,

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: He came not back: he is or ta'en or slain.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Sit thee down, Clitus: slaying is the word;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is a deed in fashion. Hark thee, Clitus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Whispers

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: What, I, my lord? No, not for all the world.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Peace then! no words.

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: I'll rather kill myself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hark thee, Dardanius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Whispers

speaker: DARDANIUS
text_entry: Shall I do such a deed?

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: O Dardanius!

speaker: DARDANIUS
text_entry: O Clitus!

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: What ill request did Brutus make to thee?

speaker: DARDANIUS
text_entry: To kill him, Clitus. Look, he meditates.

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: Now is that noble vessel full of grief,

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: That it runs over even at his eyes.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Come hither, good Volumnius; list a word.

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text_entry: What says my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, this, Volumnius:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The ghost of Caesar hath appear'd to me

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Two several times by night; at Sardis once,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And, this last night, here in Philippi fields:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know my hour is come.

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text_entry: Not so, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nay, I am sure it is, Volumnius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thou seest the world, Volumnius, how it goes;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our enemies have beat us to the pit:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Low alarums

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is more worthy to leap in ourselves,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than tarry till they push us. Good Volumnius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thou know'st that we two went to school together:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Even for that our love of old, I prithee,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hold thou my sword-hilts, whilst I run on it.

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text_entry: That's not an office for a friend, my lord.

speaker: VOLUMNIUS
text_entry: Alarum still

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: Fly, fly, my lord; there is no tarrying here.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell to you; and you; and you, Volumnius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Strato, thou hast been all this while asleep;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell to thee too, Strato. Countrymen,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My heart doth joy that yet in all my life

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I found no man but he was true to me.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall have glory by this losing day

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: More than Octavius and Mark Antony

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By this vile conquest shall attain unto.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: So fare you well at once; for Brutus' tongue

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hath almost ended his life's history:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Night hangs upon mine eyes; my bones would rest,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That have but labour'd to attain this hour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alarum. Cry within, 'Fly, fly, fly!'

speaker: CLITUS
text_entry: Fly, my lord, fly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hence! I will follow.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt CLITUS, DARDANIUS, and VOLUMNIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I prithee, Strato, stay thou by thy lord:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thou art a fellow of a good respect;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy life hath had some smatch of honour in it:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hold then my sword, and turn away thy face,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: While I do run upon it. Wilt thou, Strato?

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: Give me your hand first. Fare you well, my lord.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Farewell, good Strato.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Runs on his sword

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar, now be still:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I kill'd not thee with half so good a will.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Dies

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alarum. Retreat. Enter OCTAVIUS, ANTONY, MESSALA, LUCILIUS, and the army

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: What man is that?

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: My master's man. Strato, where is thy master?

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: Free from the bondage you are in, Messala:

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: The conquerors can but make a fire of him;

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: For Brutus only overcame himself,

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: And no man else hath honour by his death.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: So Brutus should be found. I thank thee, Brutus,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: That thou hast proved Lucilius' saying true.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: All that served Brutus, I will entertain them.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Fellow, wilt thou bestow thy time with me?

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: Ay, if Messala will prefer me to you.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Do so, good Messala.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: How died my master, Strato?

speaker: STRATO
text_entry: I held the sword, and he did run on it.

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: Octavius, then take him to follow thee,

speaker: MESSALA
text_entry: That did the latest service to my master.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: This was the noblest Roman of them all:

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: All the conspirators save only he

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: Did that they did in envy of great Caesar;

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: He only, in a general honest thought

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And common good to all, made one of them.

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: His life was gentle, and the elements

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: So mix'd in him that Nature might stand up

speaker: ANTONY
text_entry: And say to all the world 'This was a man!'

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: According to his virtue let us use him,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: With all respect and rites of burial.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Within my tent his bones to-night shall lie,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Most like a soldier, order'd honourably.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: So call the field to rest; and let's away,

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: To part the glories of this happy day.

speaker: OCTAVIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
